wikipedia_page.main: Lieutenant-General Sir Frederick Marshall  (26 July 1829 – 8 June 1900) was a British Army officer.

response: Commanding Officer: Major General Frederick Marshall.
*1890–1900 Lt-Gen. Sir Frederick Marshall. app. 29 March 1890

Lawson was born on 16 June 1890, the eldest son of Colonel William Levy-Lawson (1864–1943) and his wife Sibyl Mary Marshall, eldest daughter of Lt-Gen Sir Frederick Marshall. His father was the younger son of Edward Levy-Lawson, 1st Baron Burnham, proprietor of The Daily Telegraph and had served in the Scots Guards and then in the part-time Royal Buckinghamshire Yeomanry (Royal Bucks Hussars), with which he had won a Distinguished Service Order (DSO) during the 2nd Boer War.Burke's.Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. His first  cousin  was the  Hon. Mrs  Dorothy Coke (née  Levy-Lawson, died 1937),  wife of Major the Hon. Sir John Coke (died 1957). His  daughter Lucia wrote a  book  about Hall Barn, her home  from  age 11  and the  seat of the Baron Burnham family.
*Frederick Marshall (British Army officer) (1829–1900), British Army lieutenant general
